title: 114_s1968
content: The Act may be cited as the "Business Supply Chain Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015". The findings and sense of Congress are outlined in the Act. Congress finds that in 2014, the Department of Labor identified 136 goods from 74 countries made by forced labor and child labor. The United States, as the largest importer, faces increasing demands for information on human rights impact of products. Consumers lack standing to enforce provisions of the Smoot Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 in US courts. Courts have ruled that consumers lack standing to bring civil action in US courts for enforcing the provision in the Smoot Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 prohibiting importation of goods made with forced or convict labor. There have been fewer than 40 enforcement actions in the past 80 years due to broad exceptions for goods not produced in sufficient quantities in the US. Federal mechanisms exist to prevent and punish such practices. The enforcement actions on record in the past 80 years for tainted goods imported to the US are limited, with fewer than 40 cases. Federal mechanisms to prevent forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking in supply chains suffer from scope limitations and lack of information on tainted goods. The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act addresses these issues. The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003 and the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2005 allow for the termination of Federal contracts if a contractor engages in trafficking or uses forced labor. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2005 allows for criminal jurisdiction over Federal employees, contractors, or subcontractors engaging in severe forms of trafficking or forced labor. Executive Order 13126 prohibits the acquisition of products produced by forced or indentured child labor. Federal regulations such as Executive Orders and the National Defense Authorization Act prohibit contractors and their employees from engaging in trafficking-related activities like charging recruitment fees or confiscating passports. Federal regulations (Public Law 112-239) prohibit Federal contractors, subcontractors, and their employees from engaging in trafficking-related activities such as charging labor recruitment fees, confiscating passports, and using fraudulent recruitment practices. They must also maintain an anti-trafficking compliance plan with a complaint mechanism. Federal regulations and Executive Orders require Federal contractors and subcontractors to have an anti-trafficking compliance plan with a complaint mechanism to prevent trafficking in persons. Congress acknowledges that forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor for commercial profit are severe forms of abuse. Forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor are severe forms of abuse for commercial profit. Legislation is needed to prevent these practices and provide consumers with information on products free of such labor. Legislation is necessary to provide consumers with information on products free of child labor, forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking in the United States. Through disclosures, businesses and consumers can avoid supporting these crimes in the supply chains. SEC. 3. Disclosure of information on efforts to combat forced labor, slavery, trafficking, and child labor. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require covered issuers to disclose efforts to combat forced labor, slavery, trafficking, and child labor. Regulations will be promulgated within a year of the enactment of the Business Supply Chain Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 mandates covered issuers to disclose measures taken to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain in annual reports filed with the Commission. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 requires covered issuers to report on efforts to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain, including policies to identify and eliminate these risks. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 mandates covered issuers to disclose their policies and actions to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 requires covered issuers to disclose their policies on addressing forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain, including prohibiting employees from engaging in commercial sex acts with minors and evaluating and addressing related risks. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 mandates covered issuers to disclose efforts in evaluating and addressing risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain, including measures taken to eliminate identified risks. The Trafficking and Slavery Act of 2015 requires covered issuers to disclose efforts in evaluating and addressing risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain, including measures taken to eliminate identified risks. This includes specifying if the evaluation was conducted by a third party and if consultation with labor organizations or workers was part of the process. The National Labor Relations Act requires disclosure of consultation with labor organizations or workers in evaluating and addressing risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in the supply chain. The National Labor Relations Act mandates consultation with labor organizations or workers to address risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in the supply chain. Covered issuers must specify consultation methods, extent of supply chain coverage, and efforts to ensure supplier audits are conducted. The covered issuer must ensure supplier audits investigate working conditions, labor practices, and risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor within the supply chain. The covered issuer must establish systems to identify risks of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain and evaluate compliance with policies. Suppliers in the supply chain must attest to the ethical manufacture of materials. The covered issuer must ensure suppliers attest to ethical manufacturing practices and comply with laws regarding forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. Internal accountability standards and reporting procedures must be maintained in the supply chain management. The covered issuer must maintain internal accountability standards, supply chain management, and reporting procedures for entities within its supply chain failing to meet standards regarding forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. The covered issuer must train employees and management on issues related to forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in supply chains. The covered issuer must ensure labor recruitment practices at suppliers comply with policies to eliminate exploitive labor practices contributing to forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. The covered issuer must ensure compliance with policies to eliminate exploitive labor practices, including audits of labor recruiters and remedial action in cases of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor within the supply chain. The covered issuer must provide remedial action for victims of forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in the supply chain to prevent recurrence. Regulations require disclosure on the company website. The regulations mandate that covered issuers disclose information on their website under the label 'Global Supply Chain Transparency'. The Commission will also make this information available on its website to the public. The Commission will provide a searchable list of covered issuers on its website, disclosing measures taken to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. The covered issuer must disclose measures taken to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in their supply chain. This includes submitting information as required by the rules issued under this subsection. The term 'covered issuer' refers to an issuer with annual global receipts exceeding $100,000,000. 'Forced labor', 'slavery', and 'human trafficking' are defined as labor practices violating national and international standards. The term 'remedial action' refers to activities or systems that a covered issuer puts in place to address trafficking activity in violation of national and international standards, including relevant laws and conventions. The term 'remedial action' in the context of a covered issuer refers to activities or systems implemented to address non-compliance identified through monitoring or verification. The term 'supply chain' for a covered issuer includes labor recruiters, suppliers, and raw materials used in manufacturing. 'The worst forms of child labor' refer to violations of national laws. The term 'the worst forms of child labor' refers to child labor that violates national and international standards, including International Labor Organization Convention No. 182.
